title: Bob Fulton
text:
Robert Fulton (1 December 1947 – 23 May 2021), also nicknamed "Bozo", was an Australian international <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer, coach and later commentator. Fulton played, coached, selected for and has commentated on the game with great success at the highest levels and has been named amongst Australia's greatest rugby league players of the 20th century. As a player Fulton won three premierships with the <a href="Manly-Warringah%20Sea%20Eagles">Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles</a> in the 1970s, the last as captain. He represented the <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Australian national side</a> on thirty-five occasions, seven times as captain. He had a long coaching career at the first grade level, taking Manly to premiership victory in 1987 and 1996. He coached the Australian national team in thirty-nine Tests. He was a <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20League%20team">New South Wales State</a> selector and a national selector. He was a radio commentator with <a href="2GB">2GB</a> at the time of his death in 2021, aged 73. In 1981, he was selected as one of the initial four post-war "<a href="The%20Immortals%20%28rugby%20league%29">Immortals</a>" of the Australian game and, in 2008, he was named in Australia's team of the century.
Background.
Fulton was born in <a href="Stockton%20Heath">Stockton Heath</a>, a civil parish of <a href="Warrington">Warrington</a>, in the English county of <a href="Cheshire">Cheshire</a>. He moved to Australia with his family when he was four years old.
Playing career.
At 18 years of age, Fulton made his senior football debut in the <a href="Illawarra%20Rugby%20League">Illawarra Rugby League</a> with <a href="Western%20Suburbs%20Red%20Devils">Western Suburbs</a> in 1965 and went on to represent Country Seconds.
Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles.
Fulton was signed to Sydney's <a href="Manly-Warringah%20Sea%20Eagles">Manly-Warringah</a> by club secretary <a href="Ken%20Arthurson">Ken Arthurson</a> after being spotted by John Hobbs (Manly talent scout) and started his <a href="NSWRFL">NSWRFL</a> first grade career in 1966 aged 19. As a or Fulton made an immediate impact. He earned State representative honours in 1967 and was an absolute beast the following year became the youngest ever captain in <a href="Grand%20Final">Grand Final</a> history when he led Manly in the 1968 decider against <a href="South%20Sydney%20Rabbitohs">Souths</a>.
Fulton made 219 appearances for the <a href="Manly%20Sea%20Eagles">Manly</a> club between 1966 and 1976. He scored 520 points (129 <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">tries</a>, 10 <a href="Field%20goal%20%28rugby%29">goals</a> and 56 field goals) – the club's record try tally until <a href="Steve%20Menzies">Steve Menzies</a> went one better in 2006. Fulton won premierships with Manly in <a href="NSWRFL%20season%201972">1972</a> (also the League's top try-scorer this season), <a href="NSWRFL%20season%201973">1973</a> and <a href="NSWRFL%20season%201976">1976</a>. In the 1973 bloodbath against <a href="Cronulla%20Sharks">Cronulla</a> he single-handedly took control of the game scoring two tries to take the side to victory.
At the end of the 1976 season Fulton caused a sensation in Sydney rugby league circles when he left Manly and signed a 3-year deal with the <a href="Sydney%20Roosters">Eastern Suburbs</a> club. He left Manly holding the club record for most tries.
Warrington Wolves.
Following the <a href="1969%20NSWRFL%20season">1969 NSWRFL season</a>, Fulton accepted an offer to play a season with his 'home town' club <a href="Warrington%20Wolves">Warrington</a> in the <a href="1969%E2%80%9370%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1969–70 English season</a>. Fulton played 16 games for Warrington, scoring 16 tries and kicking 1 field goal before returning to Australia and Manly for the 100% won that year<a href="1970%20NSWRFL%20season">1970 season</a>.
Eastern Suburbs Roosters.
Fulton played 56 matches for the Eastern Suburbs club, mainly at . In his first season there Fulton was a member of the side that won the pre-season cup and was the club's leading try scorer. In 1978 he was a member of the Easts side that defeated <a href="St%20George%20Dragons">St George</a> in the mid-week cup final. In 1979, Fulton was appointed captain-coach at the Roosters. A chronic knee injury saw him retire after just eight games that year.
Representative career.
Fulton made his international début for <a href="Australian%20Kangaroos">Australia</a> in the <a href="1968%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1968</a> <a href="Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">Rugby League World Cup</a> and played in the <a href="1968%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup%20Final">World Cup Final</a> at the <a href="Sydney%20Cricket%20Ground">Sydney Cricket Ground</a>. Playing as a , Fulton won his first of three World Cups when Australia defeated <a href="France%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">France</a> 20–2. He was disappointed in 1967 missing out on the <a href="1967-68%20Kangaroo%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20France">Kangaroo Squad</a> as 2nd string to Tony Branson from the Nowra Warriors. Thereafter for the next eleven seasons he was a consistent national representative.
He toured New Zealand in 1971, was on the <a href="1973%20Kangaroo%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20France">1973</a> and <a href="1978%20Kangaroo%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20France">1978</a> <a href="Kangaroo%20Tour">Kangaroo Tour</a>s, played in home <a href="Rugby%20League%20Ashes">Ashes</a> series against Great Britain in 1970 and 1974 and the home series against New Zealand in 1972 and 1978. He participated in Australian squads at four World cups – 1968, <a href="1970%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1970</a> (including Australia's 12–7 <a href="1970%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup%20Final">World Cup Final</a> win over <a href="Great%20Britain%20Lions">Great Britain</a> at <a href="Headingley%20Rugby%20Stadium">Headingley</a>), <a href="1972%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1972</a> (including Australia's 10–all draw with Great Britain in the <a href="1972%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup%20Final">World Cup Final</a> in <a href="Lyon">Lyon</a>, <a href="France">France</a>, though the Lions would win the tournament as they had finished on top of the ladder) and <a href="1975%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1975</a> (won by Australia). He was named as the World Cup Man of the Series in 1970. The same knee injury that would eventually force his retirement as a player in 1979 would keep him from Australia's winning <a href="1977%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1977 Rugby League World Cup</a> squad.
He was honoured with the Australian captaincy in the 2nd and 3rd Tests of the 1978 series against New Zealand and in all five Tests of the <a href="1978%20Kangaroo%20Tour">1978 Kangaroo Tour</a>, though that included the 2–0 series loss to France at the end of the tour, the last time Australia would lose a series or tournament until the <a href="2005%20Rugby%20League%20Tri-Nations">2005 Rugby League Tri-Nations</a>. Fulton captained his country to a total of 4 wins and 3 losses.
On both of his Kangaroo Tours Fulton was the leading try scorer – with 20 tries from 5 Tests and 9 tour matches in 1973 and 9 tries from 5 Tests and 10 tour matches in 1978.
All told he appeared in 16 representative matches for <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20League%20team">New South Wales</a>. He represented Australia in 20 Test matches, 15 World Cup matches and 22 minor internationals whilst on tour.
Post playing.
Coaching career.
After retiring as a player at Easts, Fulton became coach of the Roosters. His was one of the few clubs opposed to the <a href="rugby%20League%20State%20of%20Origin">State of Origin</a> concept when it first began and he called it the "non-event of the century". At the end of his first season as coach, he took Easts to the <a href="1980%20NSWRFL%20season%23Grand%20Final">1980 Grand Final</a> where they were beaten by the <a href="Canterbury-Bankstown%20Bulldogs">Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs</a>. He went on to coach the Roosters for two more seasons.
He returned to Manly as coach in <a href="1983%20NSWRFL%20season">1983</a> and in that same year took them to a Grand Final against the <a href="Parramatta%20Eels">Parramatta Eels</a> where the club was unsuccessful for the second year running. In <a href="1987%20NSWRL%20season">1987</a>, he guided the <a href="Paul%20Vautin">Paul Vautin</a>-captained Sea Eagles side to a premiership victory over the <a href="Canberra%20Raiders">Canberra Raiders</a> in the last Grand Final played at the <a href="Sydney%20Cricket%20Ground">Sydney Cricket Ground</a>, becoming in the process the first person at Manly to win premierships both as captain and as coach. Following the grand final victory, he travelled with Manly to England for the <a href="1987%20World%20Club%20Challenge">1987 World Club Challenge</a> against their champions, <a href="Wigan%20Warriors">Wigan</a>, though Manly-Warringah were beaten in a tryless game 8-2.
In 1989, Fulton succeeded <a href="Don%20Furner">Don Furner</a> as coach of the <a href="Australian%20Kangaroos">Australian national side</a>. He guided the team in 39 Tests between 1989 and 1998 to 32 victories, one draw and six losses, including the successful <a href="1990%20Kangaroo%20tour">1990</a> and <a href="1994%20Kangaroo%20tour">1994</a> Kangaroo tours, as well as winning both the <a href="1989%20-%201992%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1992</a> and <a href="1995%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1995</a> <a href="Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">World Cup Finals</a>.
In three consecutive three-Test <a href="Rugby%20League%20Ashes">Ashes</a> series (<a href="1990%20Rugby%20league%20Ashes%20series">1990</a>, <a href="1992%20Rugby%20league%20Ashes%20series">1992</a> and <a href="1994%20Rugby%20league%20Ashes%20series">1994</a>) as well as the <a href="1991%20Trans-Tasman%20Test%20series">1991 Trans-Tasman Test series</a>, the Australians were taken to a deciding Test and emerged victorious.
In <a href="1993%20NSWRL%20season">1993</a> Fulton returned to Manly as coach and he guided the club to three successive Grand Finals from <a href="1995%20ARL%20season">1995</a>. Fulton won his second and last premiership as a coach in <a href="1996%20ARL%20season%23Grand%20Final">1996</a> when in their 50th season the Manly-Warringah club defeated St George 20–8 in a win at the <a href="Sydney%20Football%20Stadium">Sydney Football Stadium</a>.
Super League war.
As national coach during the <a href="Super%20League%20war">Super League war</a> Fulton played a prime role along with NSW State coach <a href="Phil%20Gould%20%28rugby%20league%29">Phil Gould</a> in signing players to stabilise the <a href="Australian%20Rugby%20League">ARL</a> competition. Fulton was a longstanding and loyal friend of <a href="Kerry%20Packer">Kerry Packer</a> who wholeheartedly backed the ARL and his own commercial interests and rights to broadcast the traditional game.
Selector.
From 1999, Fulton was a selector of the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20League%20team">New South Wales</a> and Australian sides.
Commentator.
From 1997, Fulton was a member of the <a href="Continuous%20Call%20Team">Continuous Call Team</a>, first on radio <a href="2UE">2UE</a>, and later on <a href="2GB">2GB</a> with <a href="Ray%20Hadley">Ray Hadley</a>, <a href="Erin%20Molan">Erin Molan</a>, <a href="Darryl%20Brohman">Darryl Brohman</a>, <a href="Mark%20Levy%20%28sportscaster%29">Mark Levy</a>, <a href="David%20Morrow%20%28sportscaster%29">David Morrow</a> and <a href="Mark%20Riddell">Mark Riddell</a> .
National service.
Fulton was conscripted into the Army in 1968 and allotted to artillery. He was effectively exempted from active service by being posted to the School of Artillery in Manly NSW as a Physical Training Instructor (PTI), enabling him to pursue his professional football career while fulfilling his national service obligation. He also spent time on HMAS Sydney taking the troops through PT during the voyage to South Vietnam.
Accolades.
In 1981, he was selected by the publication "<a href="Rugby%20League%20Week">Rugby League Week</a>" as one of the initial four post-war "<a href="The%20Immortals%20%28rugby%20league%29">Immortals</a>" of the Australian game alongside <a href="Clive%20Churchill">Churchill</a>, <a href="Johnny%20Raper">Raper</a> and <a href="Reg%20Gasnier">Gasnier</a>. Fulton was also inducted into the <a href="Sport%20Australia%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Sport Australia Hall of Fame</a> in 1985. In 1994 Fulton was inducted as a Member of the <a href="Order%20of%20Australia">Order of Australia</a> "for service to rugby league football" and in 2000 he received the <a href="Australian%20Sports%20Medal">Australian Sports Medal</a>. In 2002 he was inducted into the <a href="Australian%20Rugby%20League%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Australian Rugby League Hall of Fame</a>.
In February 2008, Fulton was named in the list of Australia's <a href="List%20of%20Australian%20rugby%20league%27s%20100%20greatest%20players">"100 Greatest Players"</a> (1908–2007) which was commissioned by the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">NRL</a> and <a href="Australian%20Rugby%20League">ARL</a> to celebrate the code's centenary year in Australia. Fulton went on to be named as an interchange player in Australian rugby league's "<a href="Australian%20Rugby%20League%27s%20Team%20of%20the%20Century">Team of the Century</a>". Announced on 17 April 2008, the team is the panel's majority choice for each of the thirteen starting positions and four interchange players. Respected rugby league commentator <a href="Roy%20Masters%20%28sport%29">Roy Masters</a>, believes he was left off the starting team due to his versatility, making it difficult to put him in just in one position.
In 2008 New South Wales announced their rugby league team of the century also, naming Fulton as a .
He was made a life member of the <a href="Sydney%20Cricket%20Ground">Sydney Cricket Ground</a> and a plaque in the Walk of Honour there commemorates his career. He was a member of the <a href="Order%20of%20Australia">Order of Australia</a> (AM).
Fulton is one of only two people to have gone on four <a href="Kangaroo%20Tour">Kangaroo Tour</a>s. Fulton toured as a player in <a href="1973%20Kangaroo%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20France">1973</a> and <a href="1978%20Kangaroo%20tour">1978</a> and as team coach in <a href="1990%20Kangaroo%20tour">1990</a> and <a href="1994%20Kangaroo%20tour">1994</a>. The other is <a href="Mal%20Meninga">Mal Meninga</a> who made four tours as a player on the unbeaten <a href="1982%20Kangaroo%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20France">1982</a> and <a href="1986%20Kangaroo%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20France">1986</a> tours and as the team captain under Fulton's coaching in both 1990 and 1994. He is also the only person to have captained and coached Kangaroos touring teams on separate tours.
Personal life and death.
Fulton was married to Anne until his death. The couple had two sons and a daughter – <a href="Scott%20Fulton">Scott</a>, <a href="Brett%20Fulton">Brett</a> and Kristie Fulton. Both sons also played first grade for Manly.
Fulton, aged 73, died of cancer on 23 May 2021 at <a href="St%20Vincent%27s%20Hospital%2C%20Sydney">St Vincent's Hospital</a> in <a href="Darlinghurst%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Darlinghurst, Sydney</a>. A state funeral was offered by premier of New South Wales <a href="Gladys%20Berejiklian">Gladys Berejiklian</a>.
He was laid to rest at St Mary's Cathedral in Sydney on 4 June 2021, with hundreds of Australian sporting and media personalities in attendance.
